questiontext.text:
Evaluate the sum of the infinite series :
$$\small \sum _{n=3}^{\infty }\:[-2(\frac{1}{4})^n-3(3)^{-2n}]$$

[Calculate upto 2 significant figures]

Answer :
{1:NUMERICAL:=-0.046296:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The series can be represented as follows :
-2$$\small \sum _{n=3}^{\infty }\:(\frac{1}{4})^n$$-3$$\small \sum _{n=3}^{\infty }\:(3)^{-2n}$$

This contains two geometric series where the following is given :
First term : a1 =$$\small \frac{1}{64}$$ a2 =$$\small \frac{1}{729}$$
[At n=3 the first term for both the series will be to the power 3. In the second series, the expression can be simplified by taking the square of 3 which equals 9]
Common ratios : r1 = $$\small \frac{1}{4}$$ ,r2 = $$\small \frac{1}{9}$$
Number of terms(n) = $$\small \infty$$

The Sum of a Geometric series is given by :
$$\small \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}$$ where a is the first term , r is the common difference and n is the number of terms

As n = $$\small \infty$$, Sum = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r}$$
Sum1 = $$\small \frac{a_{1}}{1 - r_{1}}$$ ; Sum2 = $$\small \frac{a_{2}}{1 - r_{2}}$$
Sum1 = 0.020833  Sum2 = 0.0015432

Total Sum = (-2) * Sum1 + (-3) * Sum2
Total Sum = -0.046296
